Award.AwardTitle: M.E.A.S.U.R.E. ? (MESA Assessment of STEM Undergraduate Retention in Education)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This research will enhance our understanding of the underlying issues affecting the differential participation and success rates of community college students from underrepresented groups in STEM fields. The guiding questions for this study are: (1) What MESA Community College Program (MCCP) activities are especially helpful in improving self-efficacy or motivation in STEM for underrepresented students and, (2) How are students' perceptions of STEM disciplines influenced by their participation in MCCP activities? This project will ascertain the value of the MESA model as a method to develop local STEM talent and learning communities among underrepresented populations in varied settings (rural/urban).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Summary

NSF HRD 1304776 Proposal: MESA Assessment of STEM Undergraduate Retention in Education

*Phyllis Harvey-Buschel, **James Dorsey, William Zumeta, ***Lucy Casale, *Elizabeth Meza

*University of Washington, ** California Community Colleges System, ** Washington State Board of Community and Technical Colleges

The Mathematics, Engineering, Science Achievement (MESA) is an outreach program with K-12 schools and higher education partnerships in ten states with a mission is to recruit and support underrepresented and minority (URM) students to pursue education and careers in science, technology engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields. This research study examined the influence of selected MESA activities, in the MESA Community College Programs on students’ self-efficacy, interest, perception, and persistence in STEM courses and majors.

The study was conducted with MESA students in Washington and California using interviews, surveys and focus groups. Because of data incomparability between the two states in data collection, variables, and access, only the Washington colleges were included in the quantitative data analyses.

Participants’ gender was nearly evenly split, 52% of respondents were male and 48% female. 71% of respondents were Latino/a, 9% Black/African American, 13% Asian or PI, 4% White/Caucasian.  Results from the surveys showed MESA students with high level of interest and perception in STEM before joining MESA and that the program helped them better understood the nuances in choosing majors and careers what how coursework and a career track may entail. MESA does seem to provide a boost to student self-efficacy and motivation to remain in a STEM major and transfer and pursue a STEM career.

In focus groups, students reflected on if, and how MESA had influenced their self-efficacy, interest, and motivation in STEM.  The reported the importance of a dedicated and welcoming study space, and having technically and academically competent peer-tutors and facilitators. The communal spaces were seen as a quiet and supportive place for group study, and more welcoming than campus tutoring centers.  A caring and dedicated staff, professional development and leadership activities that allowed students to meet and interact with a diverse group of STEM professionals had a large influence on their motivation and belief in their ability to achieve a degree.  Finally, students found important and motivating the “prestige, “rigor” and “high expectations” that MESA provides.

Students in the focus groups also expressed that the program encouraged them to take their education more seriously. Although MCCP students have a fairly high level of interest in and positive perception of STEM before joining MCCP, the program helped to understand the nuances in selecting majors and careers enhancing their understanding of what major coursework and a career in a particular discipline may entail. Students reported that the MESA community spaces was helpful for them in maintaining their interest in STEM studies.

Student outcomes variables such as - college level credits earned, STEM credits earned, and whether or not a transfer associate’s degree earned were examined. Credit accumulation, STEM credit accumulation, completion and transfer rates all appear higher than Washington state averages for community college students. Data on 524 students enrolled in a MCCP between 2011 and 2014 showed on average the students enrolled earned to-date 94 total credits, 75 college-level credits, and averaged 38 credits in STEM courses. Of the 524 students 272 earned a college award, 122 students are still enrolled, 138 students transferred within one year of last enrolling in a community college. Indications are that MCCP students earn significantly more: college level credits, STEM credits, and earn associate’s transfer degrees at significantly higher rates than non-participants.

MCCP students were significantly more likely to be Underrepresented Minorities than non-participants and significantly more likely to be female and older than non-participants. Zero order correlations also showed that age was negatively associated with college level credits and degree but positively associated with STEM credits, while being a female student was positively associated with earning a degree and with college level credits but negatively associated with STEM credits. In other words, MCCP students had stronger outcomes despite the fact that female gender and greater age in general tend to work against success in STEM. The odds ratio also indicates that MCCP participants were 2.19 times more likely to graduate with a transfer associate’s degree than comparison students who enrolled in a STEM course but who did not participate in MCCP.

References

Carlone, HB; Johnson, A. (2007). Understanding the science experiences of successful women of color: Science identity as an analytic lens. Journal of research in science teaching 44 (8), 1187-1218.

Chang, M. J., Sharkness, J., Hurtado, S., & Newman, C. B. (2014). What Matters in College for Retaining Aspiring Scientists and Engineers From Underrepresented Racial Groups. Journal of Research in Science Teaching, 51(5), 555–580.

Espinoza A. 2008. Examining the academic success of Latino students in science technology engineering and mathematics (STEM) majors. J. Coll. Stud. Dev. 49:285–300

 

 


Last Modified: 08/12/2019
Modified by: Phyllis Harvey-Buschel
